message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria (AIP). AIP is an autosomal dominant disorder, which means that each child of an affected parent has a 50% chance of inheriting the disease-causing gene mutation. Therefore, the probability of this patient having a child with AIP is 50%.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and elevated levels of porphobilinogen and δ-aminolevulinic acid suggest acute intermittent porphyria, an autosomal dominant genetic disorder. The patient has a 50% chance of passing the affected gene to her child, as it is an autosomal dominant disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and serum studies are consistent with acute intermittent porphyria, which is an autosomal dominant disorder. The patient has a 50% chance of passing on the mutated gene to her child, regardless of the gender or health of her partner.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with acute intermittent porphyria, an autosomal dominant disorder. If the patient's mother and uncle have the gene mutation, there is a 50% chance that the patient inherited the gene mutation and thus a 50% chance of passing it onto her offspring.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute intermittent porphyria, an autosomal dominant disorder. Because her mother and uncle have the disease, the patient has a 50% chance of passing the disease on to her child if her partner is unaffected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and elevated concentrations of porphobilinogen and δ-aminolevulinic acid suggest acute intermittent porphyria, which is an autosomal dominant disorder. The patient has one affected parent, so the probability of passing on the abnormal gene to each child is 50%. Therefore, the probability of this patient having a child with the same disease as her is 50%.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows symptoms of acute intermittent porphyria, which is an autosomal dominant genetic disease with a 50% chance of inheritance from the affected parent. Therefore, the probability of this patient having a child with the same disease as her is 50%.

We refer to the principles of genetics for help. The patient has symptoms and elevated serum concentrations of porphobilinogen and δ-aminolevulinic acid, which suggest a diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria (AIP). AIP is an autosomal dominant disorder with variable penetrance, meaning that the probability of passing on the disease to offspring is 50%.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and elevated porphobilinogen and δ-aminolevulinic acid levels suggest acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), which is an autosomal dominant disorder. Since the patient’s mother has the same disease, her mother must have inherited a mutated gene from one of her parents. Therefore, the probability of the patient inheriting the mutated gene from her mother is 50%. If the patient’s husband is not a carrier of the mutated gene, then their child will not inherit the disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has acute intermittent porphyria, an autosomal dominant disorder. Her father is healthy, so he does not carry the gene mutation. Therefore, she has a 50% chance of passing the gene mutation to her child.
